unnormalised: Okay, so my sabziwala, Raju bhai, is a character. A lovable, perpetually-in-a-hurry, mathematically-flexible character. Buying vegetables from him is less a transaction and more of a performance art piece. Especially when it comes to units of measurement. I swear, the man operates on a different plane of existence where kilos and grams are merely suggestions.

unnormalised: Last week, I went to buy tomatoes. I asked for 1/2 kg. Raju bhai, without even looking at the scale, just scoops up a pile and plonks it in a bag. "Hogaya, madam," he declares confidently. Looking at the meager collection, I raised an eyebrow. "Are you sure that's even 400 g?" I asked. He just shrugged, "Thoda upar neeche hota hai. What to do? You give Rs. 30." Suddenly, grams became rupees? I was bewildered.

What to do? You give rupees thirty." Suddenly, grams became rupees? I was bewildered.

unnormalised: Then there's the spinach saga. One time, I asked for a "bunch." Now, a "bunch" can mean anything from a fistful to a small shrub, depending on Raju bhai's mood. This particular day, his mood dictated a truly *epic* bunch of spinach – easily weighing 750 gm (I weighed it later, out of sheer curiosity). When I questioned the size, he just grinned, "Healthy eating, madam! Bonus for you!" I paid the Rs. 25 (bargaining is futile) and lugged my spinach shrub home. My fridge smelled like a jungle for a week.

unnormalised: And don't even get me started on potatoes. He sells them by the "dheri" – a vaguely pyramid-shaped pile. The size of the pyramid seems directly proportional to the perceived wealth of the customer. A fancy car parked nearby? The dheri magically expands to a kilo. Me, on my trusty scooter? Maybe half a kilo, if I'm lucky. I’m considering investing in a chauffeur-driven car just for grocery runs.

unnormalised: Fruits are a whole other ballgame. Mangoes are sold by the "dozen," but a dozen in Raju bhai's world can range from 10 to 14, depending on their size and his estimation of my mango-worthiness. Bananas are sold individually, but he always tries to sneak in an extra "free one" that’s bruised beyond recognition. "Bhagwan ka prasad," he'll say with a wink.

unnormalised: The real kicker? I saw him weighing ginger yesterday. He used a rock. A legit, garden-variety rock, as a counterweight on his scale. When I pointed it out, he just laughed. "Madam, same weight! No tension!" I’m pretty sure the rock weighed approximately 200 gm.

unnormalised: Despite all the unit-related shenanigans, I wouldn't trade Raju bhai for the world. He’s part of the neighborhood fabric, a purveyor of slightly-off-weight veggies and a master of charming sales tactics. Plus, he always throws in extra coriander, which, if we’re being honest, is worth its weight in…well, probably not a standardized unit. Maybe a small rock.
